content: easy mesh grocery bag whip up one of these super easy grocery bags in a few hours the trellis mesh stitch creates a sturdy but lightweight bag which will tuck into your handbag so you need never be without room to expand the bag is designed to be made from any cotton or cotton blend yarn between sport weight 5ply and aran weight 10ply - it s up to you how delicate or chunky you want to go the example shown is dk weight aus 8ply the base is worked in a 5-chain trellis stitch to make a string of small oval spaces the main body of the bag is then worked in the round in a spiral using a 6-chain trellis mesh there s no need to mark rounds - you just carry on until you have a depth of about 28cm/11 you then build in some nifty matching trellis mesh handles and you re done materials 150m/164yds/70g dk weight aus 8ply cotton yarn shown here in moda vera beetle - rust 4mm hook size the body of the bag is 30cm/12 wide x 28cm/11 deep plus an extra 2 5cm/1 for the rounds which include the built-in handles the handles can be as long as you like but i have given instructions for the shorter handles pictured gauge gauge is not important for this project as mentioned above you can use any cotton yarn from around 5ply to 10ply just check the width of your bag after you work the base see below notes  standard american terminology  trellis mesh creates holes which we ll call spaces  i ve suggested a foundation chain length rather than specifying a particular number of stitches the length i ve recommended is more than enough for you to create a good width for your grocery bag at the end of the project you just unpick any unused chains from the slip knot end back to the edge of your work see finishing off  instructions here are for right-handed crocheters instructions base make a length of chains 40cm/16 long single_crochet in 12th chain from hook then repeat chain 5 skip 5 chains single_crochet in next chain until your work is 33cm/13 wide you will have a base string like the one in the photo below the width at this stage needs to be about 2 5cm/1 greater than the bag width you want as the work shrinks in a bit after a few rounds there will be between 10 and 13 spaces including the 1st one formed by the 11 turning chains mine has 12 spaces body setup round you will now work your way back along the bottom of the string of spaces making a single crochet stitch into each of the spaces and working chain 6 between the single crochets chain 6 rotate your work clockwise so that the string of spaces is to the left of your hook then single_crochet in the space to the left of
